He was diagnosed with mild aortic valve stenosis two years ago  which was being managed conservatively with periodic follow-up echocardiograms. Previous echo 8 months ago demonstrated mild aortic stenosis. Recent cardiac stress test revealed ECG changes suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy  and a follow-up echocardiogram uncovered progression of aortic stenosis. He doesn’t have any known drug allergies and has a family history remarkable for a father who died of a myocardial infarction in his early 70's. He lives with his wife  is an occasional alcohol drinker  and denies any illicit drug use.

Patient Profile:  The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male named John  who is a former smoker and has been diagnosed with mild hypertension  which is being managed with a beta blocker. He has a history of dyslipidemia and takes a statin medication as treatment. He lives alone  has a sedentary lifestyle  and admits to a diet high in red meat and dairy products. He has no known drug allergies. He does not consume alcohol.  Presentation:  John presents to the clinic today reporting shortness of breath and chest discomfort for the past three weeks that is progressively getting worse. He describes the chest pain as a severe pressure that usually comes on with exertion  but has started to occur at rest. He also reports episodes of dizziness and fainting. He has noticed recent weight gain and ankle swelling which he attributes to “not doing much and eating the same"". He denies nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or diaphoresis.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination findings show that he is overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28. He is mildly tachypneic and his blood pressure is moderately elevated. Cardiac examination reveals a noticeable systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Peripheral edema is noted in both lower extremities.  Given this clinical presentation  an echocardiogram has been scheduled to confirm the suspicion of aortic valve stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Thompson  a 72-year-old Caucasian female  presents at the clinic expressing symptoms of fatigue  chest pain (angina)  lightheadedness  and escalating shortness of breath especially during periods of activity.   She has a past medical history of hypertension  which is being managed with Atenolol  and hyperlipidemia  which is controlled by Atorvastatin as instructed by her primary care physician. The patient denies smoking and alcohol consumption. She reports maintaining a balanced diet but leads a sedentary lifestyle. She also confirms a family history of early-onset heart disease in her father who experienced a myocardial infarction at age 56.  On examination  she showed signs of heart murmur  along with physical signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. Her EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and strain pattern while echocardiogram revealed a severe aortic stenosis with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%.  The presenting symptoms combined with her risk factors  heart murmur and echo findings all point towards a diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis. Given her age and characteristics of the valve on imaging  degenerative calcific aortic stenosis seems most likely.  The team plans to stabilize Ms. Thompson’s hemodynamics and conduct a cardiac catheterization for further evaluation with a view towards potential valve replacement.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and occasional chest pain over the past 6 months. He has also been experiencing episodes of fainting during mild exertion. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia which have been controlled with regular medications for the last 10 years. He reports being a past smoker but quit approximately 15 years ago.   On examining  his vitals are stable but he appears uncomfortable due to shortness of breath. Cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur that is heard best at the right upper sternal border and radiates to the neck. There is a delayed and diminished carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus). Based on the presenting symptoms and physical findings  a suspicion of aortic valve stenosis was considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Browning  a 76-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with gradually worsening shortness of breath  chest discomfort  and a decreasing ability to exercise. He particularly notices these symptoms when he engages in any moderate physical activities such as gardening or walking up a flight of stairs. He has noticed a substantial reduction in stamina over the last six to seven months. He also reports occasional episodes of light-headedness and a fainting spell about one week ago.   He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which are controlled with medication. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and quit smoking fifteen years ago. His BMI is within the range of overweight. Patient is not a known case of diabetes or any autoimmune or rheumatic disease.  His only surgical history includes a cholecystectomy done twenty years ago. There are no known allergies. He does not consume alcohol.   Family history is significant; his father died of heart disease in his late sixties and his elder brother has been diagnosed with heart failure. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban area. He is up-to-date with his routine health screenings and vaccinations  but has not seen a cardiologist before.   Given this history and his current presenting symptoms  the possibility of aortic valve stenosis is a prime diagnostic consideration.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of breathlessness on exertion  chest pain  heart murmur  fatigue  and episodes of dizziness. These symptoms have progressed over the past few months and he noticed he is unable to participate in some of the activities he used to do without difficulty previously.   He lives with his wife in a two-story house  has two adult children and is a retired engineer. He has been a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. He leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle and his diet is moderately high in sodium and saturated fats.  Relevant past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed ten years ago  managed with Lisinopril. His grandfather had heart disease and his father had a history of aortic valve disease. He has no known allergies. His current medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and a multivitamin/mineral supplement.  On examination  he is appeared fatigued and in mild distress. His BMI is 28. The cardiovascular exam revealed a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space  with radiation to the neck and late peaking.  In summary  based on the age  predisposing factors  clinical features  and physical examination findings  aortic valve stenosis is suspected. Further diagnostic evaluation like ECG and echocardiogram are planned to confirm the diagnosis. He is also advised on lifestyle modifications  especially diet and exercise.

Patient Presentation:  82-year-old Caucasian male presents with shortness of breath and chest pain upon exertion that has been gradually worsening over the last 2 months. He also gives a history of experiencing light-headedness on occasion  especially while climbing stairs or walking more than a block.   Demographic Details:  The patient is a retired accountant who lives with his wife at home. He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker.  Medical History:  Past medical history is significant for hypertension  which is fairly well-controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg once daily. The patient also suffers from hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily. There is a history of myocardial infarction 6 years ago  and coronary artery bypass graft surgery was performed at this time. Family history is relevant for heart diseases  including a father who died due to myocardial infarction at age 60. The patient undergoes annual check-ups regularly and has good compliance with medication and regular exercise. A cardiac murmur was noted during the last check-up  and further evaluation was recommended.   The patient is now presenting to the clinic for further evaluation and management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old African-American male  with a BMI of 28 presents today in the clinic with complaints of progressive symptoms of fatigue  difficulty in climbing stairs and dizziness for the past two months. He also reports an increasing incidence of mild chest pain and occasional shortness of breath. He denies any cough  fever  night sweats  or unintentional weight loss. He reports he feels fine at rest but his symptoms exacerbate upon exertion. His past medical history is significant for hypertension which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is controlled with medication. He never smoked or consumed alcohol and there is no family history of early heart disease. He reports regular follow-ups for his hypertension. On examination  a systolic murmur was noted.   Based on his age  history  and examination findings  aortic valve stenosis is being considered. Echocardiography and further cardiovascular assessment are planned.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: He reports experiencing episodic chest pain  shortness of breath  particularly during exercise  and feeling faint or lightheaded with exertion over the last few months.  History of Present Illness: On further questioning  he describes the chest pain as a heavy pressure sensation. He notes that his symptoms seem to worsen with increased activity  and frequent rest breaks have become necessary for him. He denies any reduction in symptom severity with rest  and notes that episodes are prolonged with greater intensity of activity. He also mentions that is become increasingly fatigued and has experienced reduction in his usual capacity for physical activities.   Past Medical History: His medical history is significant for hypertension which is well controlled on medication  and hypercholesterolemia. There is no known history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit smoking 10 years ago. His family history is significant for heart diseases.  Review of Systems: He reports weight loss of 10 lbs over the past 6 months without trying  which he attributes to a decreased appetite. He denies any symptoms of fever  malaise or night sweats.   Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Johnson appears his stated age and is in no acute distress while at rest. There was an audible systolic murmur heard over the second right intercostal space. Pulses are somewhat diminished in the lower extremities. He looks mildly pale.   Episodic chest pain  progressive shortness of breath  and fainting during exertion are associated with aortic valve stenosis. His physical examinations corroborate this suspicion. Further diagnostic tests are necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the cardiology clinic with the chief complaint of increasing fatigue  breathlessness  and occasional chest pain. She states these symptoms have been progressively worsening over the week and become more prominent with physical activity such as stair climbing or brisk walking. She also reports episodes of feeling lightheaded. Ms. Johnson has a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  which are managed with medication. She is a non-smoker and drinks socially.   Her father passed away at the age of 70 due to cardiac complications  but she is unsure of the exact diagnosis. She is concerned about her symptoms and wants to find out if her problem is heart-related given her family history. She denies any cough  fever  night sweats  lower limb swelling  or any other systemic symptoms.   Her vitals on examination show: BP - 130/85 mmHg  pulse - 70 bpm  irregular  and body mass index (BMI) - 28. A systolic murmur was noted on auscultation. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  an 80-year-old Caucasian male  presents at the clinic accompanying complaints of fatigue  chest pain and shortness of breath  especially on exertion. The patient also mentions experiencing occasional dizziness and fainting spells over the past few months. These symptoms have been gradually worsening over the last year.  Mr. Smith led a relatively active lifestyle until his retirement 20 years ago. He has a 40-pack year smoking history but quit smoking about 10 years ago. He also reports moderate alcohol consumption and has a BMI of 29. Mr. Smith does not follow a strict diet and reports a love for salty and high-fat foods. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels and has been on medication for the past 20 years. Patient had a myocardial infarction around 5 years ago and underwent a stent placement.  There is no significant family history of valvular heart disease but heart attacks appear common in his family  with his father and elder brother both suffering heart attacks in their late sixties.  Examination reveals a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard best at the 2nd right intercostal space  radiating to the carotid arteries. The murmur increased in intensity on squatting and decreased on standing and during the Valsalva maneuver.   These findings are highly suggestive of aortic stenosis. Consequently  the patient will likely undergo echocardiography for confirmation and further investigation of the severity of his condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 75-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms of increasing fatigue  shortness of breath  chest pain during exercise  and lightheadedness over the past six months. The symptoms have been progressively getting worse over this time period. The patient also reports a history of fainting spells. Aside from these  no other symptoms like fever  cough  or edema were reported.  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medications. He admits to a decades-long history of smoking but quit five years ago. He does not consume alcohol. Mr. Johnson's father died at 78 of myocardial infarction  and his mother lived till 82 and had a history of stroke. Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with early-stage aortic valve sclerosis five years ago. His last cardiac checkup was two years ago.  Physical exam revealed a midsystolic murmur heard best at the right second interspace close to the sternum and radiating to the neck. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy but no signs of ischemia and a chest X-ray demonstrates cardiomegaly. Lab tests including complete blood count  kidney function  and electrolytes were within normal limits. Blood glucose was slightly elevated.  Given the progressive symptoms and physical findings  Mr. Johnson is suspected to have aortic valve stenosis  possibly progressing from his prior aortic sclerosis. Due to the severity of his symptoms  a transthoracic echocardiography is ordered for further examination.

Patient Information: 70-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and chest pain  History of Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing progressively worsening shortness of breath and occasional chest pain over the past three months. Initially  he noticed difficulty in breathing only during moderate physical activity like walking up stairs  but now even mild activity like changing clothes and talking for prolonged periods induces breathlessness. Patient also experiences frequent episodes of chest discomfort and has had several instances of feeling lightheaded with nearly fainting twice. He denies any recent illnesses  coughing  or wheezing.   Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with high blood pressure 12 years ago  well controlled on medication  and a history of mild aortic valve regurgitation diagnosed on routine checkup 20 years ago without any specific symptomatic complaints.  Family History: Both parents died of heart disease at ages 79 and 76.  Social History: He is a retired school teacher  a former smoker (quit 25 years ago)  occasional alcohol consumer  and does not use any illicit substances.  Review of Systems: Other than mentioned symptoms  review is unremarkable.  Physical Examination: On examination  blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 76 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 per minute and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  there is a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard loudest at the right upper sternal border. No radiation of the murmur is noted. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological examinations are unremarkable.  Assessment: The symptoms and clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of symptomatic aortic valve stenosis. Referral to cardiology and echocardiography will be required for confirmation.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath  especially on exertion over the last 6 months. The patient additionally reports episodes of feeling lightheaded. She has no report of chest pain  but states her symptoms seem to be progressively worsening.  Past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and cerebrovascular accident with a full recovery 5 years ago. The patient has a 30-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. The patient also has a family history of ischemic heart disease with her father having his first myocardial infarction in his late 50s.  She has a BMI of 26. Her blood pressure reading today is 142/85 mmHg. On physical examination  a midsystolic ejection murmur was noted by the clinician. The findings suggest hypertensive heart disease  possibly complicated by aortic valve stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology clinic  with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and occasional angina. He reports that his symptoms have gradually worsened over recent months  now he is unable to walk more than half a block without needing to rest. The patient also describes occasional episodes of feeling ""lightheaded"".   He has a history of hypertension for the past twenty years  managed by Lisinopril alongside controlled type II diabetes mellitus which he monitors at home. His other past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history  but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies drug use.   There is a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father died of a heart attack at the age of 78.  On physical examination  he was noted to have a prominent systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the neck. Review of his previous records showed that this murmur was not documented in his physical exam 1-year prior.  These symptoms  in the context of Mr. Smith’s age and relevant past medical history  are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis. Further diagnostic tests including an echocardiogram are recommended to confirm diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Anne  a 75-year-old woman  walks into the clinic with chief complaints of exertional dyspnea  chest discomfort  and decreased exercise tolerance for the last six months. On further enquiry  she also reports episodes of dizziness and transient loss of consciousness. Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the past two months.  She is a homemaker  a non-smoker  and does not consume alcohol. She lives with her husband and grandson. She has a history of hypertension for 25 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years. She regularly takes metformin and lisinopril. Her family history suggests her mother had a heart ailment but she is unsure about the details.  On physical examination  a midsystolic murmur was noted on auscultation of the heart  radiating to the neck. Pulses were regular with a minimized pulse pressure. She appears worn out  tired and has a body mass index of 29.   This patient's presentation suggests a probable diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis. Further diagnostic tests  including an echocardiogram  are planned to confirm the diagnosis and ascertain the severity of the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with progressive shortness of breath on exertion  angina  and episodes of syncope over the past six months. The patient also reports a decreased tolerance for his daily exercise regimen. These symptoms have progressively worsened and have started to affect his quality of life.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed with regular medications (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). Also  he had a past medical history of rheumatic fever as a child  but no history of rheumatic heart disease. He mentions smoking approximately a pack of cigarettes per week in his younger years but had quit smoking about 20 years ago. No known drug allergies. There has been no previous surgical history. He is up to date with yearly Cardiovascular check. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died of heart failure in his late 80s. He drinks alcohol occasionally  only in social scenarios  and avoids recreational drugs. His immunizations are up-to-date  including annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccines.

Patient Information: Mrs. Sandra Thompson  a 74-year-old Caucasian female  retired schoolteacher  non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption.  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Thompson comes to the clinic today complaining of debilitating fatigue  occasional chest discomfort and difficulty with maintaining her usual level of physical activity (i.e walking her dog)  especially over the last two months.  History of Present Illness: Her fatigue has progressively gotten worse  which she attributed to her ""age"". She notes she now has difficulty climbing a flight of stairs without needing to stop and rest due to increased shortness of breath. This has never happened before. She experiences chest tightness  although it is not very severe. She denies accompanying arm or jaw pain  nausea  vomiting or diaphoresis. She has also noticed episodes of lightheadedness  but denies syncope. She further describes a harsh sound while listening to her heartbeat recently but did not think anything of it.  Past Medical History: Hypertension (managed with hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril)  hyperlipidemia (managed with statins)  and osteoarthritis. No previous surgeries or hospitalizations.  Family History: Father died in his late sixties from heart disease. Mother died at age 80 from a stroke.   Social History: Mrs. Thompson is widowed  lives alone  and has two children who live in the same city. She is a retired schoolteacher who enjoys gardening and reading. She is a non-smoker and drinks a glass of wine with dinner occasionally.  This clinical presentation is suggestive of aortic valve stenosis. The patient's age  gradually worsening exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and chest discomfort  accompanied by her history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are known risk factors for aortic valve stenosis  prompts the need for further evaluation with echocardiography.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. R  a 72-year-old Caucasian woman  presents today with some subtle changes that she's noticed over the previous few months. Recently  she has experienced increasing episodes of chest discomfort during physical activity  particularly when gardening or walking up stairs. She feels as though the discomfort is an intense pressure  and she also reports associated episodes of lightheadedness and experiencing shortness of breath more rapidly than usual during such activities. She denies any palpitations  swelling in her legs or fainting spells. She's become worried as she's also noticed an increasing fatigue  which she initially put down to aging. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension which is well-controlled on amlodipine. Her maternal uncle had a “heart problem”  but the details are unknown.  On examination  an ejection systolic murmur was heard best at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotids. There's also a noticeable delay between the apical and carotid pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus).   Her EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy. In light of the clinical findings  the symptoms of angina  exertional dyspnea  and syncope  an echocardiogram was arranged; this confirmed severe aortic stenosis  with a valve area of less than 1 cm^2.   The crush  swoosh  ding symptoms (Angina  Syncope  and Dyspnoea) along with the detected heart murmur and echo findings  and patient's age subcategorize her into symptomatic severe aortic stenosis  which is in need of urgent aortic valve replacement surgery.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Peterson  a 76-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with progressive dyspnea on exertion and slight chest discomfort over the past 6 months  especially during moderate physical activity such as climbing stairs. He had episodes of dizziness and fainting recently. Patient reports a history of increasing fatigue and occasional palpitations. No fever  cough  or any changes in weight.  Patient's history reveals hub hypertension  controlled with medication for the last 10 years. Mr. Peterson has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and is taking statins. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago and drinks socially. Relevant family history shows his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75.  No known allergies. Medications include amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  Upon physical examination  a heart murmur was noted. He had normal S1 with S2 split  a mid-systolic ejection murmur was present along the upper right sternal border. Both lungs were clear  and there were no other abnormal findings.  Given Mr. Peterson's presentation and heart murmur  telemetry monitoring was initiated. An ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern  and a chest X-Ray showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Therefore  aortic valve stenosis suspicion was raised  and the patient will be recommended for an echocardiogram for further diagnostic evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old male presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of chronic fatigue  shortness of breath  particularly with exertion  and occasional episodes of chest discomfort. He also mentions having noticed reduced tolerance for physical activities  such as walking that was usually easy for him. In the last three months  he also reports episodes of feeling lightheaded and having fainting spells.   Demographics:  Mr. A is a retired engineer  a lifetime non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  and has a BMI of 28.5 kg/m². The patient lives with his wife in a suburb of Minneapolis. His main recreational activity is golfing. He admits no illicit drug use.  Relevant past medical history:  Mr. A has a history of hypertension  diagnosed 7 years ago  for which he is taking losartan 50mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed 10 years ago  for which he takes atorvastatin 20mg daily. He also undergone a coronary angioplasty 5 years ago for anginal chest pain  and since then has been on baby aspirin therapy. He has no known drug allergies. Family history is significant as his father died of a heart attack at the age of 78.  Recent investigations:  The patient’s last annual checkup (8 months ago) showed a mildly elevated LDL cholesterol level and a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space that radiates to the carotids but his ECG was normal. The physician deemed these findings as indicative of possible aortic valve stenosis. The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment if symptoms such as fatigue  shortness of breath  fainting spells  or chest pain appear. Given the development of these symptoms  especially the syncopal episodes  further evaluation is needed to assess the extent of the patient's aortic stenosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  who presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and syncope over the last six months. He also reports occasional chest pain during strenuous physical activity. He describes the chest pain as being tight and squeezing in nature  usually resolving with rest. He is a lifelong non-smoker and a teetotaler with no known drug allergies.   His medical history is significant for hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed 10 years ago. Both conditions have been managed with medication (Amlodipine 5 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  respectively). He does not have a known history of rheumatic fever or any known heart disease.   He has not been following up with his primary care doctor regularly due to denial of his age-related health issues. However  the frequency of his symptoms had increased leading to concern in Mr. Doe  thereby seeking help.  His family history includes his father dying of a myocardial infarction at age 62  and his mother  aged 96  is alive and well. He is a widower with three grown children. One of his sons was diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his late forties.  On examination  pulse rate is controlled  blood pressure is within normal limits. Auscultation of the heart reveals a systolic murmur best heard along the right upper sternal border radiating to the neck.   Given his symptoms and findings  it will be appropriate to pursue further diagnostic evaluation to rule out aortic stenosis.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Thomas is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with complaints of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and occasional episodes of chest discomfort  most notably over the past 3-4 months. He denies experiencing any cough  expectoration  fever  leg swelling or palpitations.  His medical history is marked by controlled hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last ten years. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atenolol. He was a smoker for over 20 years but quit smoking 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies.  He also reports a reduced ability to walk as far as he was able to prior to these symptoms developing. Family history reveals that his father suffered from heart disease and passed away from a heart attack at age 73.  Physical examination reveals a lean man in no acute distress. Vital signs are: BP 132/80 mmHg  HR 88 bpm  RR 16/min  and temperature 98.6 F. Cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Dough  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented in the clinic with complaints of gradually worsening exertional dyspnea  mild angina  and occasional bouts of syncope during the past 6 months. He noted that these symptoms had been interfering with his daily activities  as he was becoming easily fatigued  particular when walking even short distances.  His medical history is significant. He was diagnosed with moderate hypertension fifteen years prior to this visit and has been controlled on Lisinopril. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin and had a single episode of acute rheumatic fever during his childhood  but no ongoing rheumatic heart disease. There was no known family history of any congenital heart diseases or any sudden cardiac deaths in the family.  He is a retired accountant who quit smoking approximately 25 years ago. He reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Upon examination  he was noted to have a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space  which radiates along the carotid arteries. EKG shows a left ventricular hypertrophy. The rest of the physical examination was generally unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old  Caucasian male  a retired engineer  non-smoker  with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presenting to the clinic with progressively worsening shortness of breath and chest discomfort. The shortness of breath is predominantly exertional  has been progressive over the past several months  and currently occurs with minimal exertion like walking up a flight of stairs. He also reports experiencing occasional dizziness and several episodes of fainting over the past 3 weeks. The patient's chest discomfort is not clearly associated with effort or rest  further precipitating the need for evaluation.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease for which he had a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 10 years ago. His current pharmacological treatment includes aspirin  a statin  and an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. There is no family history of any congenital heart diseases or early cardiac deaths.  An examination reveals a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right second intercostal sternal border  radiating to the carotids but not to the apex  increased pulse pressure  and a relatively slow rise in carotid pulse. The patient appears older than his stated age and is moderately dyspneic at rest. There are no visible scars on the chest  jugular venous pressure is elevated  and no peripheral edema is found.  A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) performed during the consultation reveals left ventricular hypertrophy and severely reduced aortic valve area consistent with severe aortic stenosis. Additional imaging and cardiology consultation are planned to evaluate the feasibility of aortic valve replacement.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Nelson  a Caucasian male aged 75 is brought into the emergency department  accompanied by his wife. He presents with complaints of frequent chest pain  borne of exertion; fatigue  predominantly while participating in routine activities; breathlessness; heart palpitations  and fainting spells. Mr. Nelson has had a considerable decline in his overall health over the last six-month period.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a strong family history of cardiac disorders including his father who passed away at 68 from a myocardial infarction. He quit smoking 10 years ago  was a social drinker  and has never consumed illicit drugs. He's allergic to penicillin  which causes him to break out in hives.  On examination  his vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate 95 beats/min with irregular rhythm  respiratory rate of 17 breaths/minute  and temperature 98.6°F. Cardiovascular exam reveals a systolic heart murmur heard best at the heart base with radiation to the carotids. He is currently under medication for his hypertension and diabetes.   The patient had no prior echocardiograms  and considering his symptoms combined with the physical examination findings  suggests likely aortic valve stenosis. Further evaluations are planned including transthoracic echocardiography for confirming the diagnosis and determining the severity.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  non-smoker  with a BMI of 23. He is a resident of Reading  Pennsylvania  living with his wife and is a father of two adult children.  Chief Complaint: He presents today with a complaint of increasing shortness of breath for the past few months  particularly during his daily walks and going up stairs  fatigue  and noted less exercise tolerance.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of arterial hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are appropriately managed with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily  and Atorvastatin 10mg daily). No history of chest pain  palpitations  or syncopal episodes.  Family History: His father had a heart disease in his early 70s. No family history of sudden cardiac death or valve disease.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable. Grade III/VI systolic murmur heard best at second right intercostal space  radiating to the carotids. No peripheral edema or jugular venous distention noted. The remainder of the examination is otherwise unremarkable.  This clinical history suggests aortic valve stenosis  likely due to degenerative calcification given the patient's age  although the final diagnosis would depend on further imaging studies such as Echocardiography.

Patient Presentation: The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male named John who presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue  shortness of breath  and chest pain over the past several months. John is a retired truck driver with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled by medications. The patient has a family history of heart disease; his father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 66. He stopped smoking 30 years ago. Recently  John noticed that his symptoms worsen while performing daily activities such as climbing stairs or walking short distances. On some occasions  he has also experienced episodes of lightheadedness and nearly fainting. John reports a chronic  low-grade throbbing chest pain  which sometimes radiates to his neck and is not radicated by rest or nitroglycerin. He denies any previous cardiac procedures  surgeries  or recent illnesses. He also denies any recent changes in weight  diet  or physical activity  or any cough  fever  night sweats  or other systemic symptoms. He lives with his wife  and she helps him to maintain his regular medication schedule.

Patient Information: Mrs. Helen White  a 72-year-old non-smoking Caucasian female  Chief Complaint: Progressive shortness of breath  chest pain  and fatigue on exertion over the past six months  History of Present Illness: Mrs. White has noticed a significant decline in her ability to perform household chores and activities that she used to enjoy such as gardening  as they leave her short of breath. She also reports intermittent episodes of chest pain  especially with exertion  and describes it as a heavy feeling rather than a sharp stabbing pain. Occasionally  she feels lightheaded and has had a few near syncope episodes.  Past Medical History: No known history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia or other cardiovascular risk factors. She had a childhood history of strep throat infections but unsure if she ever had rheumatic fever. She was diagnosed with a heart murmur around 10 years ago but was asymptomatic at that time.   Family History: Father had a heart attack in his 60s  mother had a stroke in her 70s  one brother with coronary artery disease.  Review of Systems: Denies any recent fever  chills  cough  gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms. Reports frequent nocturia and restlessness during sleep.   Social History: Lifelong non-smoker  occasional wine drinker and denies any illicit drug use.   Physical Examination: Patient appears slightly anxious but in no acute distress. BP: 135/65  HR: 86  RR:16  Temp: 98.6 F. Cardiovascular examination revealed a systolic ejection murmur  loudest in the right second intercostal space and radiating to the neck. The pulses are regular  and there is no peripheral edema. Rest of the physical examination is normal.  Laboratory Tests: Pending  Impression: The clinical picture is suggestive of aortic valve stenosis. Further investigations  including EKG and echocardiogram  are planned for definitive diagnosis and assessment of aortic valve function.

Mr. Smith is an 80-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath during his daily activities over the last 3 months. Moreover  he reports recent episodes of light-headedness  particularly on exertion  and a single episode of fainting last week. He also mentions a history of angina; he describes it as a dull chest pain that usually lasts for 2-4 minutes and occurs after a certain amount of physical activity. His family history is notable for heart disease  with his father having died of a heart attack at age 65.  Mr. Smith is a retired engineer and his past medical history is significant for hypertension which is under control with Lisinopril. He's also been noted to have a heart murmur on previous physical examinations.  He's a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He follows a balanced diet and used to walk two miles daily before onset of the current symptoms. He denies any history of drug abuse  foreign travel  or recent illness. He states his compliance with medications and says he takes his blood pressure at home weekly  and it remains within normal range.  On examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse-72/min; there is a visible systolic heave on inspecting his chest and a palpable systolic thrill on palpation. Auscultation reveals a harsh late peaking systolic murmur at the upper right sternal border.  The patient’s presentation and medical history  alongside his clinical examination findings  are strongly suggestive of Aortic Valve Stenosis. Further diagnostic investigations such as an ECG and echo cardiogram are warranted for confirmation of clinical suspicion.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known past history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He presented to the clinic with chief complaints of easy fatigability and shortness of breath upon exertion for the past three months. The patient also reports occasional chest discomfort and light-headedness  especially after physical exertion. He denies having a fever  night sweats  recent weight loss  or any other systemic symptoms.   He has a history of being a former smoker with an estimated 30 pack-year history  but quit 18 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol use and denies any illicit drug use.   Mr. Davis's father died from coronary artery disease in his 70s and his mother had a stroke in her late 70s. He is married with two healthy adult children. He is a retired engineer currently living with his wife  maintaining an independent lifestyle.  On his last cardiology check-up 2 years ago  a murmur was detected and further echocardiography suggested moderate aortic valve stenosis.  No known drug allergies are reported and the patient adheres to his prescribed medications  which include a beta-blocker and a statin. He is up-to-date with his routine health maintenance evaluations.   Given his age  family history  history of smoking  and existing hypertension and hyperlipidemia  he is at a high risk of progressive aortic stenosis. His new symptoms suggest a possible worsening of his condition. This necessitates further evaluation and more aggressive management of his aortic stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents with recent onset of exertional dyspnea and episodes of chest pain over the course of last three months. He reports that he has difficulty walking even small distances without becoming severely winded. Lately  he has also been experiencing light-headedness and episodes of near-syncope. The patient denies cough  fever  or recent illness.  The patient's past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever during his teenage years and he had an irregularly irregular pulse diagnosed as atrial fibrillation 5 years ago  for which he has been on anticoagulant therapy. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking  the cessation was achieved 15 years ago. The patient has been on chronic low-dose aspirin and antihypertensive medication (beta-blockers).  Upon examination  a systolic ejection murmur is noted  which increases in intensity with expiration. A carotid upstroke which is delayed is palpable. There is no observed jugular venous distention  lower lung field is clear and abdomen is soft and non-tender with no hepatosplenomegaly.  The rest of the history and physical examination is unremarkable. There is no family history of congenital heart diseases. From the history and physical findings  aortic valve stenosis is suspected.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: He presents with increasing shortness of breath for the past 6 months  mild to moderate chest discomfort consistent with angina  and intermittent episodes of lightheadedness  with one episode of syncope two weeks ago.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are both managed with medication. He also has a 40-year history of smoking  but quit 5 years ago. He has no history of diabetes  stroke  myocardial infarction  or rheumatic fever.  Family History: His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 65 and his mother passed away from stroke at age 77. He has two older siblings: a sister with hypertension and a brother who passed away due to colon cancer.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  heart sounds reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space  radiating to the neck. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate is 60 bpm  respiratory rate is 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. His BMI is in the normal range  serum cholesterol and lipid levels are controlled  and he has no peripheral edema.   Summary: Mr. Smith's age  sex  medical history  presenting symptoms  and physical examination findings are highly suggestive of aortic valve stenosis. Further investigations including an echocardiogram are warranted to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Alice Richards  an 82-year-old Caucasian woman  presents to the clinic complaining of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath upon exertion over the past three months. Reported episodes of occasional dizziness and fainting especially when trying to climb two flights of stairs leading to her apartment. Her family additionally notice slower movements and reduced physical activity compared to her vital function in the past.    Alice is a retired teacher living alone with home aid assistance in the afternoons. She denied smoking or illegal drug use  but admits to occasional alcohol use. She owns a cat and loves gardening.   Notably from her past medical history  Alice has been managed for hypertension for the past 10 years  and had past medical histories of rheumatic fever when she was 18 years old  but no prior cardiac surgery. However  she has been non-compliant with her hypertensive medications in recent years. She has no known allergies.   Other medications including aspirin  Simvastatin for her high cholesterol levels  and a multivitamin complex in the morning.    Her father had a stroke at the age of 75 and her mother suffered from arthritis. There is no family history of sudden cardiac deaths. Both her two children are alive and healthy.  Upon cardiovascular examination  her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  her heart rate is 78 beats per minute  and her oxygen saturation level is 94% on room air. Her body mass index is within the normal range. Cardiac auscultation revealed a harsh systolic ejection murmur. She showed no signs of anemia  jaundice  or cyanosis  and her jugular venous pressure is normal.   This clinical presentation is indicative of aortic valve stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Sullivan  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of increasing breathlessness seen particularly during exertion. He also mentions occasional episodes of chest discomfort  fainting spells  and feelings of a rapid heartbeat for over the last six months. It appears that Mr. Sullivan has been attributing his symptoms to his aging process and hence did not seek medical attention earlier. He recently noted a major deterioration  even making walking to his mailbox challenging due to breathlessness.  He has a known history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed by medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively) for the past 10 years. There is no history of diabetes  no recognized allergies  and he is a former smoker  having quit 30 years ago. His family history is remarkable for cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his older brother having a history of coronary artery disease.   The patient lives with his wife  is retired  and maintains an active lifestyle considering his age. His body mass index is within the normal range.  Based on these symptoms  there is a suspicion of aortic valve stenosis  which needs further diagnostic assessment including an echocardiogram. Immediate attention was needed due to the seriousness of his symptoms. He was referred immediately for further evaluation by a Cardiologist.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thompson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  is presenting to the cardiology clinic with a 2-month history of worsening breathlessness on exertion and occasional chest pain. He states that the symptoms began gradually and have been progressively getting worse  and now he cannot climb a flight of stairs without feeling breathless. He has also noticed lightheadedness and reports almost fainting once after his regular morning walk two weeks back.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he takes amlodipine 5mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin 20 mg daily. He had an episode of angina 10 years ago  which was treated conservatively. He does not have any known allergies. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from a heart attack in his early 60s.   His concerns about his declining ability to undertake physical activities and the recent near-fainting episode convinced him that these symptoms might be more serious  leading to his visit to our clinic.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  with a chief complaint of increasing shortness of breath  especially upon exertion  over the past few months. He further reports occasional chest discomfort and episodes of feeling lightheaded  one of which resulted in a near syncope episode.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago  both of which are managed by medication. In addition  he has a 30-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He also has a family history of heart disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at age 65. Further review of system is negative except for generalized fatigue.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  he appears slightly distressed with labored breathing. Cardiovascular examination reveals an audible systolic ejection murmur best heard at right second intercostal space which radiates to the neck. The murmur is associated with a decreased intensity of the second heart sound. His pulses are slightly delayed and decreased in volume. His blood pressure measures 120/80 mmHg and his heart rate is regular at 85 beats per minute. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. The clinical presentation and physical examination findings give rise to a working diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African American male with a history of long-standing  untreated hypertension and a 10-year history of smoking presents with exertional dyspnea  orthopnea and occasional palpitations over the past six months. He also complains of recent onset chest discomfort on exertion and two episodes of presyncope in the last month. He denies any history of rheumatic fever or familial cardiac diseases. He has no known allergies or significant psychiatric history. His current medication regimen includes Lisinopril 10mg once daily and low-dose Aspirin. He lives with his wife  has two adult children  and is retired from his job as a school teacher. He quit smoking eight years ago and drinks socially. On physical examination  there is a prominent apical impulse with a slow-rising carotid pulse. Auscultation reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard in the right second intercostal space. His ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. His BMI is 27 and vital signs are stable. This patient’s presentation is suspicious for aortic valve stenosis  with his risk factors being advanced age  smoking history  and hypertension.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Abbot is a 75-year-old African American male who presents to the clinic with growing fatigue over the last few months  shortness of breath during exercise  and a noticeable decrease in activity level. He reports a recent episode of chest tightness while climbing stairs  which resolved after a few minutes of rest. He also notes that he sometimes feels dizzy with exertion.   Mr. Abbot was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which is currently controlled with amlodipine. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes a day but quit 10 years ago. He has no known allergies. His father passed away at 80 due to a myocardial infarction. He denies any history of stroke or heart disease.  On examination  Mr. Abbot has a blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg  a regular pulse of 70 beats per minute  and a BMI of 28. On cardiovascular examination  a harsh systolic murmur is heard  best at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. EKG shows evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy.  Given the history  physical examination findings  and the presence of risk factors like hypertension  smoking  and family history  there is a strong suspicion of aortic valve stenosis. Further evaluation with echocardiography is recommended. Further history revealed no contraindications to aortic valve replacement if required  and the patient is referred for specialist review.

Patient Presentation:   A. K. is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology clinic complaining of progressive shortness of breath on exertion  chest discomfort  light-headedness and episodes of dizziness that have gotten progressively worse over the past several months. He also reports having periods of rapid or irregular heartbeat.  He has past medical history notable for ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and high cholesterol for which He takes aspirin  lisinopril and atorvastatin  respectively. He has no history of smoking but admits to drinking alcohol moderately. He is retired now but was an engineer by profession.  Family history reveals that his father underwent valve replacement surgery in his 70s and later passed away due to a complicated cardiac issue. He has one brother who also has hypertension.   On physical examination  a harsh systolic murmur is noted at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the neck  suggestive of aortic stenosis.   Resting electrocardiogram (ECG) shows left ventricular hypertrophy which is common in patients with aortic stenosis but no evidence of arrhythmia. Echocardiogram confirms thickening and calcification of the aortic valve  with reduced leaflet mobility and a decreased aortic valve area  consistent with severe aortic stenosis.   Follow-Up: The patient is scheduled to undergo aortic valve replacement surgery and is referred to a cardiac surgeon for further discussion. Pre-operative optimization of BP with his ongoing medication is ordered too.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of progressive shortness of breath  especially noticed upon exertion such as walking up a flight of stairs or carrying groceries from the car to his home  and noticed typically during the latter half of the day. He also reports occasional central chest discomfort  relating it to a heavy feeling rather than sharp pain  also mostly noticed upon exertion but lessening at rest. The patient has experienced episodes of dizziness in the past  one of which led to a near-syncopal episode a week ago. He denies orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  edema or familial heart disease but admits to being more fatigued recently.   The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled on amlodipine  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin  and a 40-pack year smoking history  although he quit smoking five years ago. He has no surgical history. The patient denies illicit drug use  consumes alcohol occasionally  and his typical diet is high in red meats and processed foods. He is retired but used to work in construction. Family history is notable for heart disease - both of his parents had myocardial infarctions in their 60s  and his paternal grandfather had a stroke in his early 70s.   The patient's symptoms  age  sex  and risk factors make aortic valve stenosis a strong consideration.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents at the clinic  complaining of chest discomfort  shortness of breath  especially during exercises or exertion  and worsening fatigue over the past six months. He has experienced a few episodes of light-headedness and dizziness recently. The patient appreciates a reduction in effort tolerance over the past few months and complaints of nocturnal dyspnea. There is no history of syncope  no palpitations  and no signs of peripheral edema; however  he has felt his heart pounding in his chest. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterol for 10 years  which is well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years but quit 1 year ago  and there is an occasional alcohol intake. He denies any known drug allergies. The family history reveals that his father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 60.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old retired engineer of Caucasian descent  presents to the clinic today accompanied by his daughter.  Chief Complaint: The patient complains of gradually worsening shortness of breath over the last six months  especially during exertion. He mentions that he has also experienced episodes of chest pain on a few occasions. He becomes tired easily and has significantly reduced his physical activities due to fatigue.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension that is currently controlled with medication. He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago  which he also manages with statins. He is an ex-smoker who stopped 25 years ago  and he denies any history of recreational drug use. There is no known family history of early heart diseases.  Physical Exam: On physical exam  Mr. Smith appears tired  but well oriented and responsive. Heart auscultation reveals a harsh systolic murmur audible along the right second intercostal space. His blood pressure is a bit low  recorded at 110/70 mmHg  with a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. Peripheral pulses are felt easily in both upper and lower limbs. His lungs are clear with no evidence of crackles or wheezes. The abdomen is soft  non-tender with no organomegaly or bruit detected. No lower limb edema is present.  These findings suggest Mr. Smith may have aortic valve stenosis  recommended for further testing like an echocardiogram. No other significant findings were mentioned in the present visit.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with chief complaints of increasing shortness of breath and chest discomfort during his daily activities for the past 3 months. He also reported episodes of syncope in the recent past.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  treated with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively for the past ten years. He denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. He also denies any history of chest trauma or rheumatic fever. His family history reveals that his father suffered from an aortic valve disorder.  On physical examination  a systolic murmur is noted on cardiac auscultation  prominent at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. His blood pressure is slightly decreased at 100/60 mmHg while his heart rate and respiratory rate are normal. A transthoracic echocardiogram was ordered showing a significantly reduced aortic valve area and increased pressure gradient across the valve  suggestive of aortic stenosis.  The constellation of his symptoms  physical examination findings  and diagnostic test result leads to a high suspicion of aortic valve stenosis. He will be referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and treatment planning.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of exertional dyspnea  and decreased exercise tolerance gradually increasing over the past six months. He also reports episodes of dizziness and angina-like chest pain during physical exertion. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is on Atenolol  and high cholesterol treated with Atorvastatin.  During his late fifties  he was a heavy smoker  accounting for a 30 pack-year history but quit 8 years ago. He has been a teetotaler since his early sixties. He has no known allergies. His father passed away at the age of 72 from heart failure and his mother had a stroke at the age of 68.  On physical examination  he appears comfortable at rest but becomes short of breath with mild exertion. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  heart rate is 70 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. A carotid bruit was noted and cardiac auscultation revealed a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids. There are no signs of heart failure.  An electrocardiogram was done at the clinic which showed left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient has been referred for transthoracic echocardiography for further evaluation. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Given the clinical findings and the patient’s age and family history  aortic stenosis is suspected. The patient has been advised to avoid strenuous activities and a follow-up appointment has been scheduled for further management once the echocardiogram results are available.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  who presents to the clinic with recent episodes of exertional dyspnea and occasional chest tightness. He also mentions episodes of dizziness and two episodes of near syncope in the past few weeks. He denies any recent chest pain  palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea or leg swelling. He has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. His alcohol intake is moderate  about 2-3 beers per week.   Family history is significant as his father died of a heart attack at 68 and his mother had rheumatic heart disease. His past medical history includes well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He had a mechanical mitral valve replacement 12 years ago due to rheumatic heart disease.   On physical examination  his vitals are: BP - 135/85 mm Hg  HR - 80 bpm  Temp - 98.6 F  RR - 20/min  SpO2 - 97% on room air. Heart sounds revealed auscultation of a systolic murmur best heard at the 2nd intercostal space on the right sternal border. Carotid pulses were felt to be diminished bilaterally. He is not cyanotic or jaundiced. The remainder of the examination was normal.   His prescriptions include metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and warfarin for his mechanical valve with good adherence confirmed by regular INR monitoring results. He is up-to-date on his immunizations and his latest colonoscopy and prostate screenings were normal.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Doe is a 79-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology clinic with chief complaints of exertional dyspnea  chest pain  and occasional episodes of syncope over the past few months. His symptoms have gradually worsened  to the point where he now reports difficulty walking very short distances without distress. He has also noted that the chest pain and dyspnea episodes tend to occur more with exercise and improve with rest.  He has a notable past medical history of chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a former smoker who quit 25 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago but reports no further cardiac events since that time. Mr. Doe is not on any anticoagulants but is currently taking Lipitor for his high cholesterol and Lisinopril for his hypertension.  On physical examination  a systolic ejection murmur is noted on auscultation of his heart  which radiates to the carotids. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse 72 bpm  respiration rate is 18 per minute  and body temperature is 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (37 degrees Celsius).  Overall  his symptoms and physical examination findings show a suspicious picture for aortic valve stenosis. Further investigations  including transthoracic echocardiography and potentially cardiac catheterization  should be undertaken to confirm the diagnosis and to assess the severity of the disease.

Patient Information: Ms. Emily is a 75-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the cardiology clinic with her daughter today.   Chief Complaint:  Fatigue  difficulty exercising  and occasional chest discomfort for the last six months.  History of Present Illness:  At its onset  her symptoms were mild and intermittent but have gradually worsened over the past 6 weeks. She now experiences episodes even when walking up to the second floor of her house. She describes the chest discomfort as a ""tight"" feeling but not really a ""pain"". Still  it is enough to cause her to stop and rest. She notes the cessation of symptoms at rest. She reports no associated breathlessness  palpitations  syncope  or lower extremity edema but experienced significant light-headedness one time during her morning walk.  Past Medical History: She has a known history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril. She was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia seven years ago treated with Atorvastatin. She underwent an appendectomy in the 70s and a bilateral mastectomy twenty years ago for breast cancer  from which she has been in remission since then. She has no known allergies.  Family History:  Her mother suffered a stroke at age 85  and her father died from a myocardial infarction at age 65. She has two older brothers  one with Type II diabetes and another who died from colon cancer at age 78.  Social History: She is a retired school teacher  lives with her husband in a two-story home. She is a non-smoker and rarely drinks. Her daughter help keeps her company as she is socially active in her church and enjoys playing bridge with her friends.   Objective Findings:  On cardiac examination  a mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard loudest at the right upper sternal border. Lingering breath sounds bilaterally with no added sounds.   Considering her age  symptoms  and the presence of a mid-systolic murmur  an echocardiogram will be arranged to examine the suspicion of aortic stenosis.

Patient Information: A 78-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with complaints of a two-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  especially with exertion.  History of Present Illness: The patient also identifies symptoms of occasional chest pain and dizziness. He states his symptoms are worse when climbing stairs or going for walks. He also mentions fainting spells  fatigues  and occasional palpitations. The episodes of chest pain are most often relieved with rest.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of diabetes and hypertension which are well managed on oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensive medicines respectively. He has also been a lifelong non-smoker and non-alcoholic with occasional consumption.  Family History: His father had issues with heart valves and his mother battled diabetes and hypertension.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  a systolic murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border and radiating to the neck (carotids) is evident. Examination of pulses shows a slow-rising  reduced volume in the carotid pulse (a parvus et tardus). The patient is afebrile and other vitals signs are normal.  Preliminary Diagnosis: The signs and symptoms indicate a possible diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis. Further investigations are needed in the form of echocardiography and other relevant tests to confirm this.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John  a 75-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the outpatient cardiology clinic with recent symptoms of exertional dyspnea  chest discomfort  and episodes of near syncope. He reports the occurrence of these symptoms over the last several months  which he initially attributed to his age and sedentary lifestyle. Mr. John is a retired truck driver with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well managed with medication.   These conditions are currently managed with Lisinopril 20mg once daily and Atorvastatin 40mg once daily  respectively. Additionally  Mr. John also had an angioplasty at two separate coronary artery sites 10 years back. Mr. John leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle  smokes occasionally  and drinks alcohol within recommended limits.   On examination  a mid-systolic ejection murmur was noted  as well as decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes bilaterally. Based on these findings  the suspicion of aortic stenosis has been raised  and an echocardiogram has been ordered.  Family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father  who had a fatal heart attack in his late 50s. His mother lived into her 80s and had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The patient has three adult children who are all in good health.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Henry Johnson is a 70-year-old African American male presenting to the office with recent onset of breathlessness while engaging in moderate physical activities such as climbing the stairs or gardening  which he used to manage with ease. He also complains of episodes of lightheadedness  palpitations  and a single fainting incident while working in the yard last week. He also mentions chest discomfort—tightness and pain that radiates to his back. He and his wife also observed some swelling in his ankles.   Mr. Johnson has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years  which is under control with medication. He also has a 30-year history of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago. He has a familial history of congenital aortic valve stenosis as his mother had it. He also underwent a dental procedure three years back where he had developed a minor infection post-surgery.  On auscultation  a systolic murmur was observed. His blood pressure reading was a bit on the lower end. Given the symptoms  family history  and past medical history  there is a suspicion of aortic valve stenosis. A referral was made for an echocardiogram and other relevant tests to confirm the diagnosis and take further action as necessary.

Patient Information: A 74-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic for a routine check-up.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports a recent increase in fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional lightheadedness over the past six months. Particularly  he experiences chest discomfort and tiredness following physical activities such as climbing stairs or carrying groceries.  History of Present Illness: The symptoms have been gradually worsening over the last six months. Initial symptoms were quite mild  but the conditioner has progressed to significantly impact the patient's daily activities. He denies any palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or peripheral edema.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are controlled with Losartan and Rosuvastatin  respectively  for the past ten years. He quit smoking fifteen years ago and does not report any alcohol or substance abuse. He has not had any surgeries in the past. His father died of a myocardial infarction in his 70s and his mother had a stroke in her 80s.   Physical Examination: When auscultating the heart  a systolic murmur is heard best at the right second intercostal space which radiates to the neck  consistent with aortic stenosis. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.  Patient's vitals are; Blood pressure: 145/85mmHg Heart rate: 76 bpm Respiratory Rate: 15 bpm Oxygen Saturation: 96% on room air Temperature: 37.1 C  Based on the symptoms and physical finding  the patient was suspected of having aortic valve stenosis and was referred for an echocardiogram for confirmation and severity assessment.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with consistently increasing fatigue  particularly on exertion  and episodes of mild lightheadedness. He reports that his symptoms have gradually worsened over the last six months. Recently  he has begun developing a severe breathlessness even with minimal activity. He also notes that sometimes he feels a tightness or pressure in his chest.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol levels  for which he takes medication prescribed by a family physician. His surgical history is unremarkable. He has a history of smoking about 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years.  On social history  he is retired and lives with his wife. He consumes alcohol occasionally – approximately 2-3 units per week.  On family history  his father had a heart attack at the age of 75 and his mother had long-term hypertension.  The combination of his increasing breathlessness along with the tightness or pressure in his chest  and his relevant family history  suggests aortic valve stenosis. This suspicion would be strengthened by a physical exam that reveals a systolic heart murmur and confirmed by an echocardiogram that shows decreased aortic valve area and velocity.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents to our cardiovascular department with complaints of progressive exertional dyspnea accompanied by episodes of angina and syncope in the past few months. He reports increasing fatigue and weakness resulting in decreased ability to perform his daily activities. His past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension  which are managed with regular medications. He is a former smoker  having quit about 15 years ago  after a smoking history of 30-pack years. He denies any known family history of cardiovascular diseases. His BMI is 28 and he lives a sedentary lifestyle. He does not report any relevant surgical history. He also denies any allergies to medication.  Examination reveals a visible systolic heave on his chest and the palpation confirms a forceful apical impulse. Auscultation shows a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space which radiates to the neck  along with a softened or absent second heart sound.  The above clinical picture  along with his age and features suggesting left ventricular hypertrophy  make aortic stenosis a strongly suspected diagnosis to consider.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. C  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional chest pain  especially during exercise. He also reports episodes of feeling like he is about to faint upon standing or light exertion. Mr. C has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He also reports a previous history of rheumatic fever as a child  though he states it was ""a long time ago"". He has been a smoker for about 40 years but quit approximately ten years ago. Mr. C's father had heart disease  and his mother had a stroke  which he attributes to her heavy cigarette smoking. He typically adheres to a high-fat diet and is infrequently physically active. He acknowledges that his symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past six months.   His physical examination reveals a significantly decreased intensity of the second heart sound  along with a systolic ejection murmur heard best in the right second intercostal space  radiating to the neck. The murmur is associated with a slow carotid upstroke. An ECG performed in the office shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. His heart rate is 78 beats per minute and blood pressure is 146/90 mmHg.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with a BMI of 28  presented complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath following mild physical exertions such as climbing stairs or lifting light objects. He also reported episodes of dizziness and fainting in the past recent weeks.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension since his mid-40s which has been well-controlled on two anti-hypertensive medications. He had myocardial infarctions at the ages of 52 and 58  both times managed with angioplasty and insertion of drug-eluting stents. He was placed on low-dose aspirin and statins. His Lipid profile shows an LDL of 100 mg/dl  HDL 45 mg/dl  and triglycerides 150 mg/dl  wich has been stable for years. His father had a history of angina and died an early death from suspected cardiac disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Daniel  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  has presented today with a chief complaint of worsening fatigue and dyspnea on exertion for the past six weeks. He also reports experiencing episodes of lightheadedness while performing routine tasks and occasional chest discomfort associated with moderate exertion that resolves at rest. The patient resides in a suburban area with his wife and has retired from his job as a school teacher a few years ago.  Daniel is a non-smoker and adheres to a moderately healthy diet. His alcohol intake is limited to occasional social drinking. He was previously physically active but has reduced his activities due to the mentioned symptoms.  His past medical history is significant with a diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medications (lisinopril 10 mg daily and atorvastatin 20 mg daily) for these conditions for five years and reports good compliance. There are no known allergies. His family history is positive for heart disease  his father having passed away from a heart attack at a relatively young age.  He has no previous surgical history  and his recent routine blood workup  including a lipid profile and renal function tests  were within normal limits. Of note  his last echocardiogram  performed a year ago  showed signs of mild aortic stenosis.  Given his age  family history  and current symptoms  there’s a suspicion of progressive aortic valve stenosis  which requires further investigation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia who presents to the cardiology clinic for a routine follow-up. He reports a progressive onset of exertional dyspnea over the past 6 months  along with a recent episode of syncope last week during physical activities and recurring chest pain. He denies any fevers  night sweats  or recent weight loss. He also mentions experiencing palpitations. He has a 50-pack year smoking history and quit 10 years ago. Medication regimen includes Lisinopril and Simvastatin. Echocardiogram from last year showed mild aortic stenosis.  On physical exam  he appears in no acute distress  vital signs stable.
